title: brexit deal brussels theresa may jeremy hunt
story: The Foreign Secretary said European leaders must be flexible to get a deal which can make it through Parliament.And Brexiteers threaten a day of reckoningRemainers manage to keep Britain in the EU past the March  deadline.This afternoon Theresa May will make a public appeal to the EU to fix the existing deal so the UK doesnt get trapped in the Irish backstop.Shes expected to say: The decisions that the European Union makes over the next few days will have a big impact on the outcome of the vote.Mr Hunt told the BBC: History will judge both sides very badlywe get this wrong.We want to remain the best of friends with the EU. That means getting this agreement through in a way that doesnt inject poison into our relations for many years to come.Thats what the UK has said we want to do, its what most people in the UK want and feel very strongly about.But it does need the EU also to be flexible in these negotiations and understand that we now have a very, very clear ask.We know what it would take to get a deal through the House of Commons, and that is for a signicant change to allow the Attorney General to change his advice to the Government and say we couldnt be trapped in a customs union forever.Frankly I think future generations,this ends in acrimony, will say that the EU got this moment wrong. And I really hope they dont.Government law chief Geoffrey Cox has run into trouble during talks in Brussels after EU officials rejected his demands for a fix to the backstop.Ex-Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab last night warned that voters will revolt against any attempt to wreck our EU exit.Appearing on Question Time, he blasted: Are we going to effectively be put in the position that it’s either a bad deal or no Brexit Frankly, I thinkthere’s that kind of establishment stitch-up to try and frustrate the process of Brexit, there will be a day of reckoning with the voters.Because I think the one thing people expect is to get Brexit done and dusted on March .MPs will vote for a second time on Mrs Mays deal on Tuesday.If the withdrawal agreement is defeated, they will then have a choice between a No Deal Brexit and delaying our departure date.Today George Eustice, who quit as a minister over Brexit, insisted the country is ready to leave without a deal in three weeks time.He said Britain and the EU could enter a nine-month transition period where the UK kept European rules to avoid interrupting trade.The two sides would then use that time to put permanent arrangements in place for a free-trade agreement.John Major and Gordon Brown have both demanded an extension of the Article  process to consult the public on how to carry out Brexit.In separate interventions, they both suggested a three-month delay wouldnt be enough for MPs to reach agreement on a deal.Mr Brown told Sky News: I regret to say this but Parliament has, unfortunately, proved itself totally incapable of resolving the Brexit issue.The only way to deal with this impasse is to have an extension of the negotiating period.But an extension for three months would be inadequate because it would just be the same old squabbling.And Sir John wrote in a letter to The Times: Leaving the EU would be turbulent.But logic, common sense and the national interest suggest that an extension of one year would give us the time to depart with dignity and grace, and in good order.Of the other two living ex-PMs, Tony Blair backs a second referendum while David Cameron has remained loyal to Theresa May and supports her deal.Theresa May is fighting to fix her Brexit deal

title: brexit 5 fast facts you
story: NewsBrexit:  fast facts you need to know this morning with  days to goThere are just  days left to Brexit and the prospects of a deal are bleak. Heres everything you need to know this Friday morningShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political EditorNicola BartlettPolitical CorrespondentDan Bloom:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsAll the signs suggest shes nothing new to say "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May is heading to the Leave-backing town of Grimsby today for yet another speech on Brexit. But all the signs suggest shes nothing new to say. Theres been no breakthrough with the EU and the clock is definitely ticking. Here are the main things you need to know about Brexit this morning.  Theresa May will today make a desperate plea to the European Union to grant changes to her Brexit deal that could help it get past MPs. It comes after Attorney General Geoffrey Cox ed from Brussels talks empty-handed – and bizarrely referenced his plan’s nickname, “the Cox codpiece”. “What I’m concerned to ensure is that what is inside the codpiece is in full working order,” he said, of his aim to get changes to the controversial Backstop. Cabinet ministers have privately admitted they expect the Prime Minister’s plan to be defeated by a substantial margin in next week’s crunch second vote. Both EU and Downing Street officials are downbeat about the prospect of a breakthrough on the Backstop – and without one, Mrs May will struggle to get Tory Brexiteers on side. She will say in a speech in Grimsby today: “It is in the European interest for the UK to leave with a deal. We are working with them but the decisions that the EU makes over the next few days will have a big impact on the outcome of the vote.” But shadow Brexit secretary Keir Starmer said: “This speech looks set to be an admission of failure.” It came after Chancellor Philip Hammond warned Tory Brexiteers thatthey vote down the deal they risk a softer departure from the EU. ... And a dire threat of poison  Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt today warned the EU to be flexible - or it would inject poison into its relationship with the UK for many years to come. “This is a moment of change in our relationship between the UK and the EU, he told BBC Radio s Today programme. “And history will judge both sides very badlywe get this wrong. “We want to remain the best of friends with the EU. That means getting this agreement through in a way that doesn’t inject poison into our relations for many years to come.”  Top universities have urged the government to lower the salary threshold for skilled workers coming to the UK. The Russell Group said the pound, minimum would limit the ability to hire the migrant workers the UK needs, and warned it would discriminate against part-time employees. They say it would be an own goal not to do so. Instead, the body - which represents  leading UK universities - called for the threshold to be dropped to pound,. It warned that a failure to lower the level would mean around a third of all roles - , positions - at Russell Group universities would not be open to migrant workers. Around % of the posts are currently filled by EU nationals, it said. . The cruel benefit freeze needs to end in a No Deal Brexit  A right of centre think tank has said the Government should slash taxes, fast-track infrastructure projects and end the benefits freeze to offset an economic shockthe UK leaves the European Union without a deal The Centre for Policy Studies said Chancellor Philip Hammond would have scope for a pound billion fiscal stimulus to incentivise investment and put money in consumers pockets in a no-deal scenario. And it said that the UK should also unilaterally cut import tarfs to zero wherever possible, to ensure that Britain sends out the signal that it is open to business from the rest of the world. Meanwhile, the Bank of England can be expected to take monetary steps, such as cutting interest rates, to help shore up confidence. CPS director Robert Colvile said that reassuring consumers and businesses will be vitalthe UK crashes out of the EU without a Withdrawal Agreement. . Gordon Brown wants Brexit delayed for a YEAR  Former Labour PM Gordon Brown joined business leaders and trade unionists to call for a year-long delay to Brexit to prevent the “national political disaster” of leaving the EU on the wrong terms. The former prime minister said an extension to Article  was inescapable to avoid chaos on the scheduled March  departure date from the European Union. He said: The logic of extending Article  is now inescapable to avoid chaos on March  and prevent an impending national political disaster.

title: dwp benefit freeze hurled 200000
story: NewsDWP benefit freeze has hurled , into poverty reveals damning reportThe freeze on most working-age DWP benefits is due to start its fourth year in a row from April ShareCommentsByDavid HughesDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAR NewsChancellor Philip Hammond is being urged to use next weeks Spring Statement to end the freeze "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Tories cruel benefits freeze has pushed , people into poverty, a damning report warns today. Chancellor Philip Hammond is being urged to use next weeks Spring Statement to end the freeze on most working-age benefits a year early.But that looks unlikely - as MPs already signed off the fourth year of freeze in a vote earlier this week.Research last month warned benefit caps and freezes since  are now costing the average family pound to pound, per year. Now social reform think tank the Joseph Rowntree Foundationhas issued shocking new figures.  The JRF said the freeze means the support people receive in  will be worth .% less in real terms thanpayments had risen in line with inflation. The group said , had been pushed into poverty by the first three years of the freeze, including around , children. JRF chief executive Campbell Robb said: As a society, we are failing in our duty to do everything we can to protect each other from poverty. Ministers have indicated that they do not think the freeze should be extended beyond . And its holding back working parents who want to give their children a decent le. Its time to stop turning the screw. The Government must scrap the benefits freeze and create a social security system that works for everyone when they need it. title: george osborne gives extraordinary magic
story: NewsGeorge Osborne gives extraordinary magic money defence of his austerity cutsThe ex-Chancellor claimed it was simply easier to slash the public purse - but theres one really basic thing he didnt mentionShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video george-osborne-says-raising-taxes-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailGeorge Osborne last night gave an extraordinary defence of his austerity cuts that critics say have fuelled an explosion in food banks and kne crime. The ex-Chancellor was unrepentant when asked by the Mirrorhis cuts to police, mental health and social care had fallen in the wrong places or gone too far. Instead he said there was no magic way to fund public services after the  financial crash. Extraordinarily, Mr Osborne claimed he was forced to wield the axe more harshly after U-turning on the pasty tax and a levy on charity donations. Claiming hed faced a straight choice between hiking tax or cutting services, he said: It was a lot harder raising taxes than it was cutting spending.Yet what the ex-Tory MP didnt mention was he alsocuttaxes by billions of pounds per year.  As Chancellor he slashed Corporation Tax from % to % by , raised the inheritance tax threshold to poundmillion for couples and axed the p top rate of income tax. Mr Osborne faced the question after giving the annual Cudlipp Lecture, sponsored by the Daily Mirror, on The Politics of Journalism. The now-Evening Standard editor said: Im not going to rehearse all the arguments about coming into office, there being no money left, having to take lots of dficult decisions to deal with that... But I will make this observation - it was a lot harder raising taxes than it was cutting spending. Almost all the big political problems I had came when I tried to increase peoples taxes.  Mr Osborne gave the example of the pasty tax - an extension of VAT to hot takeaway food - and the so-called charities tax, both of which were abandoned. You know what the charities tax was  Which I had to retreat on, was humiliated on  he said. It was that rich people should pay some income tax per year. Now rich people dont pay anything taxable because they give all the money to a charitable foundation, have done for decades, and then they live off the capital growth of their income. And I was forced into a humiliating retreat by the British press and lots of reputable charities. He added: So I found it really dficult to increase taxes.  And fundamentallyyou want things like more police, more money in social care and the like youve got to pay for it. You cant borrow that forever. Soyou want to make that argument to the people you have to raise taxes. And it has to be an honest argument to the people. dont pretend that some oligarch or some offshore tax haven is going to pay for it all. The real money the Treasury gets is from income tax, VAT, National Insurance. The harsh reality, he said, was that parties had to find a happy medium between tax hikes and spending cuts. I would love to have found some magic way to conjure up the money to police... but it wasnt there, he said. It came as Mr Osborne faced a wide-ranging QA after the annual lecture.He admitted theres clearly a problem with Islamophobia in the Tory party, but claimed it was not on the same scale as Labour anti-Semitism. He said he would not have joined the Independent Grouphe was still a Tory MP - though sympathised with Labour centrist MPs who had. And he claimed the majority in the Commons is around a Norway plus type Brexit - suggesting we may well end up with a customs union.

title: international womens day sees five
story: NewsInternational Womens Day sees five generations open up on being a woman in Christina Seddon is  while little Aliyza Irvine is just  months old - and they will both have vastly dferent experiences of leShareCommentsByLaura ConnorHelen Whitehouse:,  MAR NewsFive generations of the Seddon family in one room "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThere is no denying the world has changed dramatically over the last eight decades and the Seddon family have seen it all. As we celebrate International Women’s Day on Friday, five female generations of them tell us their experiences of being women in . The Merseyside family welcomed their fth generation, adorable baby Aliyza Irvine, just last year, with proud great-great grandmother Christina Seddon a whole eight decades her senior. Christina was born in the s, while Aliyza is getting set to mark her first birthday next month. Incredibly, all the women still live within two miles of each other in the Bootle and Walton areas of Liverpool – but they have all had very dferent experiences of le in the th and st centuries. Christina Seddon,    I was born in December, , and le in post-war Liverpool for a young girl like me was brilliant. I have had a lovely le. I was one of nine children, and we had a really close, extended family. My first job was at the Williams Toffee factory and I worked in pubs and as a cleaner while raising my children. I got married when I was  and had nine children with my husband George, who worked at the Albert Docks. We had a lovely five-bedroom house. In the s, it was nice to have all these children. Every one of them was perfect. I loved being a mum. But, of course, it wasn’t all easy for women. We didn’t have a washing machine or a fridge and I would wash the clothes in the baby’s bath and peg them up in front of the fire. We got by. Sadly, George died  years ago, and I don’t go out as much as I used to. But I still love dancing and will still have a little dance at the pubI go out. Me and George used to like going dancing. I used to love wearing those s glamorous dresses and the swing skirts. I do feel like we live in a very dferent world today. There doesn’t seem to be as much innocence and the streets don’t seem like a safe place. I see my grandchildren all the time. It’s so nice to keep connected with the younger generations and keep busy, it keeps me young – along with the dancing. Christine Williams,    It was fantastic being a teenage girl in the s, the best time to be a teenager. I was born in  and, as the eldest of nine, I always had someone to play with. One of my memories is of dressing up my eldest brother, Tony, in girls’ clothes. I left school at , met the kids’ dad David at  – we orced in  – and was pregnant by the age of . It was the norm for me to follow that path, and I now have four children. I think women now handle things in a better way, and don’t automatically rush into having babies. They focus on their careers more. But I never look back. I have worked all my le and do part-time work as a barmaid at the moment. One of the amazing things about being in my s in  is I feel like I am in my s. I think women have outgrown men nowadays and have got a bit more of a voice – which can only be a good thing. Independence goes a long way. Sarah Irvine,  As a kid, we had a community club where we all went, and I’m still best friends with a girl who lived on my street because we all stayed in the same area. It’s not the same now. I don’t think there is that sense of community for younger girls. When I was  I used to be a dancer in clubs. My mum would look after Lois as I’d get back in around .am. We used to go out wearing hot pants and crop tops. I think I loved it so much because I was so active, my entire family are active. My grandma Christina never stops. After I finished the dancing I started caring for people, helping with their shopping and their medication. All I ever wanted was for Lois to come first and I think she feels the same way about Aliyza. People say to me: “I can’t believe you’re nearly .” But I think I’m in my prime. Women get better with age. Lois Irvine,   I love being part of a big family of women. My mum raised me on her own and she did her best for me. Without them, I wouldn’t be the person I am today. We all live very close to each other and I see them a lot. I look up to my great nan, Christina, because she’s always out shopping, she’s always busy – she’s a glam-ma. I wake up and enjoy being with my daughter and spending the day with her. I’ve always been working, in hotels, but then when I got pregnant I had to stop. But Aliyza is nearly one and she can go to part-time nursery soon. I love it that I can be independent and earn my own money. I want to raise my daughter the same way. I wouldn’t want my daughter to rely on anyone but me. I had her at , a similar age my mum had me and my grandma had her – but I think things are dferent for me. For one thing, my baby’s dad Jordan is still in the picture and helps me out with child care. For me, it was just me and my mum and my nan helped out. My mum always made me feel loved. It’s what I want to do for my daughter. Aliyza Irvine,  months  Mum Lois says: I want Aliyza’s le to be stable and good. We will be able to do more things in five years, I want to be able to take her on holiday and take her to places. I want to take her to Disneyland Paris – something I did as a child. It was the best experience, seeing the princesses. I think things are dferent now with social media and tablets. I won’t be giving her one of those until she’s a bit older. She’s got mates as well, she’s very social. I want her to have mates at school, I want her to have friends on the street like I did growing up. I’ll be happy with anything she does when she was my age – as long as she studies. I’d like her to go to university. I want to teach her to be independent and I want her to be herself, know who she is as a person and not rely on anyone. But, I don’t want her to be lonely, my friends have children and we see each other all the time. I’m hoping they will grow up and be best friends. I always felt loved and never bored growing up. That is something that I want for Aliyza. I always want her to feel like that.

title: man smiles selfie boss who
story: NewsMan smiles for selfie with boss who minutes later buried him alive in shallow graveDarren Bonner, , was choked unconscious by Richard Spottiswood before being dumped naked in a hole behind a dry stone wall in NorthumbriaShareCommentsByLucy Varley:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsDarren Bonner [C] with killer Richard Spottiswood [L] and Spottiswoods partner Lucy BurnLtd"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA chilling selfie shows a groom-to-be smiling with a man who would moments later choke him unconscious and bury him alive in a shallow grave. Darren Bonner was killed by his employer, Richard Spottiswood, who left him to suffocate in the cruel attack. Darren, , posed for the image taken by Spottiswoods girlfriend during a weekend away in a rural caravan park. But shortly afterwards Spottiswood, , ambushed the young mechanic and placed him in a headlock before throttling him until he passed out. He then dumped him naked in a hole behind a dry stone wall and left him to suffocate under a mound of soil.  Darren was found by a passing hiker walking along a coastal path. He was pulled to the surface, but had already suffered severe brain damage and he died  days later in hospital. It emerged Spottiswood, of South Shields near Newcastle-upon-Tyne was running a drug trafficking racket and wrongly believed Darren had betrayed his operation to a rival dealer. This week the victims fiancee Donna Churchill spoke for the first time about the tragedy after Spottiswood was jailed for le for murder.  Spottiswoods girlfriend Lucy Burn, , was jailed for  months after admitting assisting an offender. She was cleared of murder. Miss Churchill, , of Sunderland said: The whole thing was heartbreaking but that chilling picture of them together almost killed me. I felt sick to my stomach at the sight of it. Darren looks absolutely tiny next to his hulking boss. My Darren didn’t stand a chance against him that night. I’d never liked the way Spotty treated Darren and never really understood why Darren stayed involved with him or continued working as a trainee mechanic at the garage Spotty owned.  All it took was a message from him to completely change Darren’s mood. He spoke to him like dirt and gave him all the awful jobs he didn’t want to do himself. I begged Darren to cut ties, but he wouldn’t. Shortly before he was murdered, we’d had a bit of an argument about it and I’d told him to leave because I didn’t want him around my kids. My heart ached but I couldn’t condone something illegal going on under my roof. He was brilliant with my children, which made my decision even harder. When I met Spotty I hated him instantly, so I asked Darren to come back to my house where I felt he belonged.  But Darren told me he couldn’t, and his eyes were filled with sadness. I knew he feared Spotty but couldn’t understand why. Something was holding him back.” Newcastle Crown Court was told the killing occurred in July  after Darren had joined Spottiswood and Burn for a weekend away at Cresswell Towers Caravan Park. A “heated argument” broke out during which Spottiswood choked Mr Bonner and then believing he was dead, loaded him into the back of a van before dumping him in the shallow grave he had dug nearby. Mr Bonner was found lying in the foetal position with a broad ligature mark around his neck and his body was covered with bruises, scratches and  blows from a ‘rod-shaped weapon’ on his back.  Miss Churchill said: Darren had tried to call me before he went away but I’d been with friends and missed it. I was sick of hearing about Spotty anyway, so I was partly glad I didn’t have to listen to anything more about it. Two days later though, I still hadn’t spoken to him and began to feel uneasy. Just then, I spotted two men walking across the car park towards me. One of them was carrying a folder and when I spotted the words ‘serious crimes unit’ and I had a gut feeling something was terribly wrong. I remember my mouth going dry as they walked in and watched as they approached my boss. Then, I was called over and taken into a back room where they told me they had bad news about Darren. As soon as they said it, I told them Spotty was responsible for whatever had happened. I just knew. I just cannot comprehend the circumstances in which he’d been discovered. It seemed so sick to imagine that he’d been buried alive. He was treated like an animal.  Spottiswood, who denied murder, told the court he had killed Darren in self-defence but ordering him to serve a minimum of  years in jail, Judge Stephen Ashurst told him: Mr Bonner died an untimely, violent and undignied death. He wanted to fit in and belong. He was much-loved and looking forward to the future but by your actions, he was deprived at such a young age of making something of his le. Detective Chief Inspector Andy Fairlamb of Northumbria Police, said: The fact that Darren was left in such a critical condition, barely breathing and lying in a shallow grave, absolutely shows how truly cold and despicable Spottiswood is.

title: no deal over brexit mean
story: NewsopinionNo deal over Brexit will mean UK learns same brutal truth our miners didMiners ed to work  years ago and without a deal they were picked off one by one before their industry faded awayShareByPaul Routledge:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsopinionMiners at a demonstration at Maerdy Lodge Colliery in Gwent "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt was  years ago this week that Britain’s coal miners went back to work after their epic -month strike for jobs. With brass bands playing, union banners aloft and families pushing buggies, they marched proudly to the pits with heads held high. Across Yorkshire, South Wales, Durham, Lancashire, Scotland and Kent, the stirring picture was the same. Nothing like it would ever be seen again. And nothing could disguise the brutal truth that they ed to work without a deal on the issue that provoked the dispute: pit closures. With no agreement, they were vulnerable to arbitrary decisions about their future. They were picked off one by one, and today their industry – which put the Great in Britain – has vanished.  The parallel is not exact, but the country faces a similar position in our orce from the European Union. Without a deal, we will be at the mercy of greater powers such as the USA – which insists that we eat chlorinated chicken – China and  unforgiving EU states. The stakes are as high for us today as they were for the miners in . It’s about survival, and Theresa May’s mantra – “no deal is better than a bad deal” – is self-defeating.  Any deal is better than no deal. As the countdown to Parliament’s meaningful vote on Brexit reaches its th hour, MPs should remember what happened to the miners, and not let it happen to us. If I were a Labour MPI would vote for the withdrawal agreement coming before the Commons any day now. It may not be perfect, it may be the shabby compromise that Vic Feather of the TUC always talked about. But it’s better than stepping, eyes closed, into the void.

Perhaps for future trips the Duchess could consider less carbon-intensive modes of travel.” William and Kate routinely use helicopters for public visits, most recently to Blackpool on Wednesday. Kensington Palace told The Sun: “Travel decisions are based on a number of factors, including effective use of time, security and minimising the impact on others, while ensuring the full schedule can be delivered.”

title: shoreham airshow pilot cleared over
story: NewsShoreham Airshow pilot cleared over  deaths says Im truly sorry for my partAndrew Hill was today found not guilty of manslaughter following a trial at the Old BaileyShareCommentsByDave Burke:,  MAR NewsPilot Andrew Hill was today cleared of manslaughter "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe pilot cleared of manslaughter following the Shoreham Airshow disaster has said he is truly sorry following the deaths of  men.A jury today unanimously found Andrew Hill not guilty as family members of those who died wept.Hill, , was attempting a loop when his Hawker Hunter jet exploded into a fireball on the A. Maurice Abrahams,  Dylan Archer,  Tony Brightwell,  Matthew Grimstone,  Matt Jones,  Graham Mallinson,  Daniele Polito,  Mark Reeves,  Jacob Schilt,  Richard Smith,  and Mark Trussler, , were all killed. Incredibly Hill survived after being thrown clear from the burning wreckage. Speaking outside the Old Bailey following the verdict, Mr Hill read out the names of the  men who died in the crash and said: Im truly sorry for the part I played in their deaths.   Some of the victims were watching the display from a grass verge near the Shoreham Airport entrance on the A, while others were in cars travelling on the road or crossing it on foot, jurors had been told. The majority were not even there to watch the airshow, with  dying instantly and the cars and their occupants being completely destroyed by the crash, prosecutor Tom Kark QC said. Hill was flown to hospital with le-threatening injured and placed in an induced coma before being discharged a month later. The not guilty verdicts were announced on Friday after jurors deliberated for just over seven hours during three days.   Victims families wept in court as the unanimous verdicts were given as Mr Hill stood in the dock. Outside court, Leslye Polito, the mother of the youngest crash victim, Daniele Polito, , said she felt disappointed, very upset and primarily let down by the justice system. She said: The whole fact that it was avoidable, that was the hardest bit to consider and process. Its still the hardest bit.  Sarah Stewart, a partner at Stewarts, who represents most of the bereaved families, called for a wider investigation to prevent future tragedies. She said: It is now almost four years since the Shoreham Airshow disaster killed  innocent men. The bereaved families have had to painfully re-live the circumstances of their loved ones death again and again. The families want answers and a verdict will go some way towards that. But it is only one part of the jigsaw.

title: jayme closs kidnap suspect denies
story: NewsJayme Closs kidnap suspect denies thinking like serial killer in prison letterAccused Jayme Closs kidnapper Jake Patterson says hell plead guilty in letter handwritten from his prison cellShareByTalia Shadwell:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsJake Patterson is accused of killing James and Denise Closs and kidnapping their -year-old daughter, Jayme "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe man accused of kidnapping -year-old Jayme Closs and murdering her parents has penned a prison letter saying he cant believe what he died.Jake Patterson wrote to a US TV reporter saying he planned to plead guilty to murder and kidnapping charges after allegedly holding the teenager captive in his cabin.A photo of the letter sent to a KARE-TV reporter reads Im sorry Jayme! written in big balloon letters.Patterson is accused of shooting Jaymes parents in Barron, Wisconsin, and abducting the teen last October. It is alleged he then held Jayme captive for months in his remote cabin in the woods in Gordon, Wisconsin.  After  days captive, she managed to escape in early January. Jayme was discovered walking down a road in the freezing without a coat or gloves in the freezing cold by a former social worker. I cant believe I did this, Patterson reportedly wrote, the New York Post reported. The letter was sent in response to questions from the reporter, in which he was asked what led him to kidnap Jayme.Patterson wrote: Its not black and white.In the handwritten jailhouse letter, he wrote that no one knew about his victim, and he would force young Jayme to hide when his dad visited the cabin on Saturdays.  Prosecutors claim Patterson killed Jaymes parents - James and Denise - and abducted the schoolgirl from her family home on his third attempt. They allege he had abandoned two previous attempts to take the teen because he saw cars parked outside the familys home, and lights on. Patterson reportedly told police he target Jayme at random after seeing her board a school bus near her house.  He learned his alleged victims names in media coverage of a case, according to a criminal complaint filed against him. In the jailhouse letter, he went on to say he took issue with the police version of events, saying they had twisted his words. He claimed he had not planned the kidnapping as thoroughly as detectives had alleged, instead calling it a complicated decision, and an impulse. I dont think like a serial killer, the letter reportedly said.Asked by the reporter what he would have doneJayme had not escaped, Patterson reportedly wrote: Wont say. It was really stupid looking back.

title: international mens day foolish men
story: NewsWhen is International Mens Day  Foolish men who ask this are getting owned on TwitterComedian Richard Herring is responding to each and every person who asks this question on International Womens day - and its all for a good causeShareCommentsByZahra MulroySocial Audience Editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsFor the last time, until next time, its  November "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIts International Womens Day today but hey, dont let that distract you from the real burning question here. WHY IS THERE NO INTERNATIONAL MENS DAY  Ignoring the inconvenient truth that every day is pretty much International Mens Daythere is in fact such an occasion.So dont get your boxers budgie smugglers in a twist, menfolk, because its happening later this year on  November. This irritating question dominates Twitter every year on  March. Luckily one man is actually doing more than his fair share to tackle it, and his efforts also help a very good cause. Comedian Richard Herring is once again spending International Women’s Day answering this eternal question with some polite trolling and raising money for Refuge. Here are some of his greatest hits so far this year...  Last year, he raised pound, for the charity and this year he is again asking his , followers on Twitter to support this act of polite trolling and raise more money for charity.People can donate to the campaignhere. International Men’s Day has in fact been around since , but has, alas, struggled to embed its way into the global consciousness in the same way as International Women’s Day. Still, its nothing a quick Google search cant sort out.   Since , there have been just over , tweets about International Women’s Day which is almost ten times the number of tweets about International Men’s Day.Last year, Herring’s Twitter followers raised over pound, for Refuge in support of his painstaking efforts to answer every single person asking this question on the social media . Herring has set up a GoFundMe page to raise money again this year.  Richard himself said in a statement: Last year, I was overwhelmed by the response to this piece of polite trolling and the amount of money raised, but having performed this service for the last few years, Im assuming that everyone will know when International Men’s Day is by now , so Im hoping to have a relatively quiet day tomorrow, though Ive been saying that for the last  years and it’s just got worseanything. Sandra Horley, chief executive at Refuge, said: We are absolutely thrilled to have Richard’s ongoing commitment to raising awareness and money for Refuge on International Women’s Day.Every day, we support over , victims of domestic violence in the UK an issue which affects one in four women in this country today and claims the lives of two women every week.The money raised last year helped us to continue to run our le-saving and le-changing services – and we very much hope that Richard will be able to raise signicant funds for our essential services this year .

title: mums horrible name baby two
story: NewsMums horrible name for baby with two unfortunate meanings ides parentsThe mum-to-be was worried that it wouldnt age wellShareCommentsByZahra MulroySocial Audience Editor:,  MAR NewsOne mum-to-be s choice has come under fire "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAs much as you may love your choice of baby name at the time, theres always a danger it may not age well. Theres also a chance that it will come back into fashion, but this isnt always a guarantee.After all, Nigel has sadly been languishing on the endangered list for quite some time now.So you cant blame one mum-to-be for testing the waters with a baby name she loves. While some people agreed with her and thought it was lovely, others described it as horrible.  Explaining a little bit about her background on Reddit , she wrote: My fianceacute and I are international intercultural -hes Indonesian and Dutch, and Im Dutch and American, which means that whatever names we choose need to sound good in each of our languages.Many of the traditional English names I love are no-goes for this reason, because they sound beautul in one language and awful in another. With this in mind, she and her partner have settled on Vesper. But she has her doubts about the name too...  The mum-to-be then adds: First, its pretty modernso Im worried it might age poorly. title: pregnant mum unborn baby girl
story: NewsPregnant mum and unborn baby girl die suddenly together days before due dateJanay Johnstone, from Auckland, New Zealand, who was due to give birth this month, had posted exciting and loving Facebook posts before she died unexpectedly aged ShareCommentsBySophie Evans:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsJanay Johnstone died suddenly this week, along with her precious unborn child "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA pregnant mum and her unborn baby daughter have died suddenly together in a double tragedy just days before her due date.Talented photographer Janay Johnstone, , who was nine months pregnant with her little girl, passed away unexpectedly earlier this week.Her precious unborn baby could sadly not be saved. Janay, whose cause of death is currently unclear, and her childhood sweetheart Mark had waited a long time for their miracle second child.The couple, who also have a toddler son Tiare, had been accepted for IVF when they found out they were expecting again, loved ones say.Their baby daughter was due to be born this month. Janay, from Auckland, New Zealand, had been seemingly healthy before her death, with no signs that anything was wrong during her pregnancy.   A kind-hearted woman, she had volunteered for Heartfelt, a selfless group of professional photographers who capture photos of families in hospital.She would take pictures for parents whose babies were very sick, or had died, so they could have valuable keepsakes, the New Zealand Herald reports.Her family told the newspaper that her death this week was sudden. They said the expectant mother was laid back and independent, with her le revolving around aircraft technician Mark and three-year-old Tiare. It was a very long process to conceive Tiare and they had been accepted for IVF when Janay got pregnant with baby number two, her grieving sister-in-law, Lana Mitchell, told the Herald. It was a miracle. Janay, who had trained as a graphic artist, had been with Mark for  years - and married for seven - after they met in a nightclub as teenagers.She ran her own business, Tee-Jay Photography . On the firms Facebook page, she describes herself as the face behind the camera and proud mum to little Tiare, with another on the way. She says: My passion for newborn photography started with my son, the moment I watched my son being photographed as a newborn, I thought would be the best job in the world! Working with the most precious little miracles, what more is there to love. As a mum I know how fast our babys grow, especially in their first year . My sons newborn baby portraits are priceless to me and I have them proudly displayed on my walls - I would love the opportunity to do this for you too. She posted what would be her final message on the page on Tuesday. She excitedly wrote: Some big news for our growing family, we are moving to the beautul Central Otago in May! Just days earlier, she had shared a picture of herself and Mark on her own Facebook page, saying: Always having a laugh with this guy x. Ollie Dale, president of the NZ Institute of Professional Photography, said Janay was vibrant and a popular member of the photographic community. He said of her death: As far as I know she had no health issues, it was completely unexpected and she was a vibrant and bubbly person. He has now set up a Givealittle fundraising page in the mums memory, where people can donate to help her husband and little boy.A post on the page reads: It is with deep regret that we mourn the passing of Janay Johnstone. A we, a mother, a photographer Janay was a wonderful mum to her beautul boy and so excited to meet her wee girl due this month. She was bubbly and vivacious with a heart of gold. Janay was an incredibly talented photographer, and an absolute baby whisperer. She will be greatly missed. Among her other endeavours, Janay was a Heartfelt photographer, giving herself and her precious time for other families who suffered their own tragic losses. Janay and her unborn baby girl sadly passed away together. It adds: If you would like to donate to help Janays husband Mark and Janays family, please do so here. All funds go directly to Mark. So far, more than ,has been raised. Janay and her baby daughter are now resting at home, according to local media. They will be laid to rest by loved ones tomorrow. To donate to the fundraising page, click here

title: andrew davies making real progress in bid to help dundee avoid relegation
story: Andrew Davies has told boss Jim McIntyre he’ll be back ahead of schedule to help Dundee escape the drop.The central defender joined the club at the start of January but broke his foot in his first outing in dark blue in a bounce game.The -year-old former Ross County skipper was expected to play a big role in the Dens gaffer’s survival bid but has had to look on from the sidelines.He spent a few weeks recovering down south recently but is back in Dundee and on the training pitch, eager to gain his fitness to be able to finally make his bow for the Dens Park club.Jim said: “Davo is back running.“He’s made real progress over the last couple of weeks.“Sunderland gave us permission to use their anti-gravity machine which has helped bring him on so we’re thankful to Jack Ross for that.“It has helped but he’s over six weeks now, will be seven weeks tomorrow so he’s where we expected him to be.“Hopefully, he can shave a week off it but we’ll pick it up day by day and see how he feels.“Him being him, he’s telling me it’ll be sooner than that because he’s desperate to get out there.“What we don’t want is any recurrence so we’ll be guided on how he is feeling.”Davies has been joined by goalkeeper Jack Hamilton this week after the stopper had a wire removed from his broken finger after surgery at the start of the year.Jim added: “Jack is coming on fine. He got the wire out of his finger last week.“He can start his comeback proper and he’s keeping Andrew Davies company at the moment – they’ve done a lot together on the bikes and they’re doing running on the training ground so it’s great to see them coming back.”Meanwhile, two bodies he’d like back sooner are nearing aand Jim is hoping he’ll have his striking options boosted for Saturday’s home clash with Hearts.Frontmen Andrew Nelson and Craig Curran missed the - defeat to Rangers last midweek but have a chance of athis week.“They are coming on, slow,” Jim said.“They aren’t back on the training ground yet but we’re hoping we’ll have at least one back training by the end of the week.“Craig had an injection in his stomach last week which has settled down nicely but it needs time.“Nelson is his heel which he picked up celebrating his goal at Livingston.“Again that is better but it’s not fully away yet.“What we don’t want to do is bring him back too early and there is a recurrence.“We’ve tried a couple of dferent things but he was tender last week and we had to back off.“It was better over the weekend so we’ll see what he’s like by the end of the week.”At Ibrox, Jim opted for on-loan forward Scott Wright to lead the line in an attempt to catch Steven Gerrard’s Rangers on the hop with pace and will have that option again. However, he’d welcome goalscorer Nelson and “focal point” Curran back.The Dens gaffer said: “Craig has been a focal point for us and brings a lot of people into play in terms of the work he puts in and how he doesn’t let defenders settle.“We went for pace against Rangers by putting Scott Wright up and pace on the sides with Jesse Curran and Andy Dales.“That wasn’t an easy decision because we had Kenny Miller’s experience there as well but we felt we could get down the sides of them when their full-backs went forward but we met them on a night when they were excellent.”

title: businessman claims he has had to lay off staff because dundee council owe me 15k
story: A businessman claims he has been forced to lay off staff due to an unpaid cleaning bill of £, from Dundee City Council.Graeme Thomson, owner of Bedazzled cleaning company, said he had been waiting two months for the local authority to settle the debt.He said his company had been cleaning the homes of council residents on behalf of the local authority’s social work department for the past five years, without any issues.But the payments stopped after Graeme switched his business’s status from a limited liability company to a sole trader, voluntarily putting his old company name into liquidation.Graeme, , said that despite producing all the documentation needed to prove he was still running a business, the council was yet to pay up.He said: “This is work the council appoints me to do on its behalf.“It is now due me £, for cleaning work I have done since last summer.“I have regularly invoiced the council for payment but it has not paid me this money despite repeated requests.”Graeme estimated that since January he had been in touch with the council at least  times asking for payment.He added: “They just keep delaying it. This is money the council is due me and it’s money I needmy business is going to survive.”Graeme said he previously employed about  cleaners but since January he had been forced to lay off eight because his company’s income has taken a hit.He said: “I can’t afford to pay wages so I’m being forced to carry on with just a few staff left.“If I don’t get paid then I definitely risk losing everything.“I don’t understand what’s going on and why the council keeps stalling and won’t pay me the money it is due me.”Graeme has now been forced to contact a solicitor to act on his behalf in his bid to be paid.A council spokesman said: “We are now investigating claims for payment that have been brought to our attention and will contact Mr Thomson to discuss this further.”

title: council set to allow coffee shops and nurseries to move into successful dundee technology park
story: The council has unveiled plans to boost Technology Park by allowing a wider range of businesses to use the site.And development chiefs have hailed the “success” of the park, which is more than three-quarters full.Council chiefs hope to welcome in a wider range of businesses in the Tech Park – so long as they compliment its existing offering.The park already hosts an Oranges and Lemons nursery, which is popular with parents who work on the estate – and businesses such as that, or an on-site coffee shop, are likely to be welcomed.However, the council has warned that businesses that any such bids will have to “serve employees based in the Technology Park rather than draw further traffic into this employment area”.Gregor Hamilton, head of planning and economic development, will make a pitch to councillors next week to lt planning restrictions currently in place.Together with city development boss Robin Presswood, Mr Hamilton is hatching plans to take back derelict buildings from owners and work with business chiefs to promote the Tech Park anew.He will tell members on Monday current rules permitting only offices and manufacturing facilities “narrowly restrict” the potential role it has to play in Dundee’s economic growth.Mr Hamilton will say: “It is clear the Dundee Technology Park has been a success and signicantly contributes to key employment sectors within Dundee.“Through improved joint working with key stakeholders, the park can be positively promoted with the support of Dundee City Council to build up the unique business park setting.”A number of key buildings, including a graffiti-covered block that looks on to Riverside Avenue, remain vacant and are falling into disrepair.Two of the park’s empty units hold almost % of the total empty space available at the park.One proposal from Mr Hamilton is that the council could apply for a compulsory purchase or sale order to seize unsightly buildingsowners refuse to take action.West End Labour councillor Richard McCready said he was glad to see action being taken.“We need to make sure Tech Park is fit for the st Century and promote jobs by working together with owners, Scottish Enterprise and anyone with Dundee’s best interests at heart.“The park has to play as much of a role as it can and it can do better than it has been. I hope this report is not a one-off, and we keep monitoring it to make sure it remains an important source of jobs.”Alison Henderson, CEO of Dundee and Angus Chamber of Commerce, said: “Tech Park is a gateway to the city for those coming in from Perth or who come along Riverside – as a first impression it can be mixed.”

title: dundee city centre nursery may close due to government policy
story: A city centre nursery has warned parents it could close.The Ark Nursery on High Street has informed customers and staff it could be forced to shut its doors on May .The owners say the closure could take place due to a number of issues, including staff resignations and changes to government policy.Jeremy Auld, chair of the board of Ark directors, said no final decision has been made but without a change in the company’s circumstances, closure is likely.In a letter to parents, Mr Auld said: “Due to a number of recent resignations by five directors on the grounds of family, work and health reasons – including our nursery manager – the board has been considering for some time the work required to continue caring for children safely.“The main reason for launching this consultation now are the recent director-level resignations and dficulties recruiting a new nursery manager and other replacement directors.“We have found it increasingly dficult to make the Ark nursery financially sustainable following changes in government policy in a number of areas and the general climate in the private sector provision of child care.”Concerns regarding the Scottish Government’s changes to early years provision have been echoed by National Day Nurseries Association Scotland.CEO Purnima Tanuku said: “We have been warning the Scottish Government about this for years but particularly in the run-up to the roll-out of funded early learning and childcare in August .“Private nurseries are really struggling to deliver quality early learning and childcare on the very low hourly funding rates they are given for funded places.“Dundee has the second-lowest rate in the country, with providers paid just £. per hour for three and four-year-olds.“Nurseries wanting to deliver , hours from August  will have to pay their staff the living wage, but how can they do this without the hourly funding rate increasing substantially “NDNA Scotland will continue to meet ministers and policy makers to make sure they work with all types of childcare providers so they can remain sustainable. For government policy to result in closures is just unacceptable.”A Scottish Government spokesperson said: “It is, of course, concerning to hear of any nursery considering closure, and the obvious effects this might have on staff, parents and children. In such cases, we would always encourage all parties involved to work together to resolve any issues that have surfaced.“Local authorities and providers operate best in partnership to deliver the increased entitlement to early learning and childcare.“As part of this, we are providing the funding to local authorities to enable them to signicantly increase the hourly rates paid to providers and to pay the real Living Wage to all childcare workers delivering the expansion from .#This is on top of  per cent business rates relief that day nurseries already enjoy.”

title: dundee drink driver 22 told cops she didnt have her keys while hiding them in her underwear
story: A banned motorist who denied drink-driving despite having the car keys in her pants has avoided a jail term.Caitlin McDonald, , was also found with cocaine while out in the city centre last month.Dundee Sherf Court heard she tried to flee from police before lying to them, telling officers she didn’t have the keys to her car.Police conducted a search after tracking her down and finding them in her underwear. The offence came almost a year after McDonald was disqualied from driving for  months.Police became aware of security guard McDonald driving in the city centre in the early hours of February .After spotting the officers, McDonald was seen to reverse her car “at speed” into a car park on St Andrews Street.Depute fiscal Lora Apostolova said: “Officers saw her abandon the car and run off into the car park.“Later that same night, the same police officers traced her. She was asked to release the keys and she said she did not have them.”The keys were later recovered from McDonald while she was at police headquarters on West Bell Street.McDonald, of Wolseley Street, pleaded guilty to driving while disqualied, testing  mics of alcohol in ml of breath, exceeding the limit of  mics, attempting to pervert the course of justice and possessing a Class A drug, namely cocaine.Sherf Lorna Drummond said: “It seems to me quite obvious custody would be warranted.“You are obviously a danger to the public and yourself when you are driving.”Instead of jail, McDonald was ordered to carry out  hours unpaid work, was placed on a restriction of liberty order for  weeks, keeping her indoors between pm-am, and given  months’ supervision.She was also disqualied from driving for  months.

title: dundee gaffer mcintyre delighted at signing winger josh todd
story: Dundee manager Jim McIntyre is “delighted” to have secured the pre-contract signing of winger Josh Todd.The -year-old has impressed at Queen of the South over the past year and the Dens Park boss says he’s been a fan of the former St Mirren man for a while.The Tele revealed back in January the Dark Blues were making a move for the Englishman to bring him in at the end of his contract after he shone for the Doonhamers in their - Scottish Cup draw at Dens Park.Todd set up the opening goal for Stephen Dobbie and was a constant menace to the home defence – something Jim is hoping to see from the midfielder in his side next season.He said: “Josh Todd is a player I have liked for a while.“I went to watch him a couple of times before we played them and he did exceptionally well and then did really well in the game here at Dens.“I’m delighted we managed to do that so I’m looking forward to seeing him in the summer.“He’s not a traditional winger that’ll hit the byline but he makes great runs beyond the strikers and he’s got a goal in him.“He’s an athlete, he can get up and down the pitch, has really good conditioning and knows where the goal is.“He’s also quick. You can’t have enough players with pace.“He’s played No  as well and he fits the bill in terms of the type of player we want to bring to the club.”Despite the club’s immediate future unclear as they battle relegation from the Premiership, that’s not stopped Jim putting preparations in place.In the immediate future, however, is Hearts on Saturday at Dens Park.Jim was at Firhill on Monday night to watch the Jambos draw - with Partick in the Scottish Cup and is hopeful his side can repeat their - success at Tynecastle last month.He added: “We had a really good result against them last time.“They’ve had a wee sticky period with injuries but we know we’ll have to defend better than we have because we will be tested.“I always feel we have a chance of winning games, especiallywe can get our strikers fit and, with the wide players we have, I feel we are always going to create.”

title: dundee owners make fresh bid to supporters society to increase shares
story: Dundee FC’s owners have made a fresh bid to boost their control in the club to over %.The Tele revealed in January that Football Partners Scotland , the majority shareholder owned by Tim Keyes, had made a move to buy the ‘A’ Ordinary shares owned by the Dundee Football Club Supporters Society.With those came rights of veto regarding a range of issues including a stadium share or potential merger with another club.That was knocked back by the Society and now Dundee finance director David Gray has written to them in an attempt to buy their Ordinary shares to bring FPS’ holding to .%.This would allow them to claim Group Tax Relief to offset losses made by the club. A deadline of March  has been made by the club for the Society to decide on two proposals put forward by Dundee FC.The first would see FPS buy the Ordinary shares for £,, the club’s preferred option. These shares have a nominal value, at  pence per share, of £,.The second is for DFCSS to “agree to support resolutions which increase the club’s share capital and then allot shares specically to FPS”.Currently there is no provision in the Society’s rules to sell shares and an extraordinary general meeting would be needed to change that, and with it a vote by its members.The Financial Conduct Authority would also need to be contacted, a process which could take months.DFCSS already had a board meeting scheduled for next Tuesday and will discuss the proposals and their response as a board as well as with their members, despite the sharp time constraint.In a statement, the club added: “At a time when our primary focus is on retaining our Premiership status, we would prefer not to have to undertake an unnecessary time consuming and expensive full share issue and we hope that the Society will support us in agreeing to one of the suggested options.”

title: embrace title race pressure urges dundee uniteds reynolds
story: Mark Reynolds says the pressure is only going to increase on Dundee United as the season nears its end but he’s backed the Tangerines to embrace it by running down leaders Ross County.The Staggies have a five-point advantage on Reynolds  Co. going into United’s final  matches of the campaign and the on-loan Aberdeen man expects the intensity to increase game by game in the race to promotion.He said: “You need to embrace the pressure.“If you are in a team that’s got aspirations to go up and compete in the Premiership you need to deal with pressure.“There are players that don’t deal with that but they don’t play in big teams.“We have a good enough dressing-room and boys who want it and are used to playing under pressure in big games.“Everyone has the capability of thriving in it and that’s what we need to do.“We just need to keep on winning. Ross County will just keep doing what they do but the good thing is we play them twice so it can still be in our hands.“If we beat them in those games then it starts to put the pressure on but we still need them to slip up to make up the eight points.“We’ve left ourselves a lot to do but all we can do is win the games in front of us.“Regardless of who it is, every game will be huge and three points will be massive.”After the disappointment of losing Sunday’s Scottish Cup quarter-final against Inverness, United are targeting an immediateto their recent good league form with  points picked up from their last  available.They take on bottom side Partick Thistle this weekend at Firhill and Reynolds has urged the Terrors to “step up” and grab the three points.He added: “It was disappointing on Sunday and the boys were hurting – it’s right we feel that disappointment and let it sink in before getting back to training yesterday and then focus on the league.“We realise that was a chance to get in a semi-final but the next  games will be like cup finals.“There will be pressure, teams will try to stop us, they’ll make it horrible and we’ll be a scalp.“Teams will want to take points off us but we need to deal with that, step up and find ways to beat them.“If we keep winning then the pressure will increase and increase and it’ll get harder and harder but we need to deal with that.“We need to step up and,we do that, then we’ll have a good chance.”After a testing double header against Inverness Caley Thistle last week with a league win followed by that cup defeat, Reynolds expects the Highlanders to be a handful for their semi-final opponents – whether it’s this weekend’s opponents Partick or Premiership Hearts.He said: “Inverness are a big physical team – they put the ball up the park and play off the back of it and they have good players in amongst that.“Last Tuesday I thought we stood up to that and we won more balls, picked up more seconds and did enough to keep them out.“We didn’t do that on Sunday, we were second to too many balls.“Inverness can do that to teams. They will cause problems.”Reynolds, meanwhile, is happy to see no astroturf surfaces on the horizon after missing recent away trips to Queen of the South and Falkirk on physio’s orders.“That’s the last game on plastic pitches so, unless we go to the play-offs and have to play on one it’ll be fine.“It was just too early, that’s me not long back from a cruciate ligament injury so the advice from the physios was not to play on it and not risk it.“They were the guys that got me back so it would be daft not to listen to them.”

title: former dundee united defender harry souttar called into australian squad
story: Former Dundee United defender Harry Souttar has been called into the Australia U  squad.The -year-old, who is on loan at Fleetwood Town from current employers Stoke City, has accepted a call-up for Australia’s Olympic qualication squad for their training camp in Malaysia and qualiers in Cambodia.Souttar has already represented Scotland at U  and U  level and, along with brother John, is poised to be the first Scottish siblings to play for dferent countries.John made his international debut last year after Hearts boss Craig Levein warned Scotland risked losing him to Australia because he was eligible to play for the Socceroos.Harry had previously insisted it was his dream to play for Scotland.He#s eligible to play for Australia through his mother, who was born in Australia.He stressed two years ago during Scotland U ’s Elite Round qualiers in Czech Republic he was desperate to play for his country.He said: “My ambition has always been to play for Scotland. Who knows, maybe one day I will partner John at the centre of defence for Scotland.“My aim is to try to get myself established in English football and then see what happens.”But Socceroos boss Graham Arnold, who is also in charge of the U  side, insists he’s delighted to have persuaded the former Tangerines and Ross County stopper to follow in the footsteps of Hibs winger Martin Boyle and pledge their future for Australia.The Aussies were alerted to Souttar’s availability by his Stoke City team-mate Adam Federici.Arnold said: “When you look at Harry and his size, he is a beast. However, he is also very good on the ground, too, with his feet and we will take a good look at him.”

title: if they werent there already it is must win time for dark blues
story: Before I start, let me open my big book of cliches and get some of them out of the way.First off the bat, in defence of this piece, cliches are only cliches because they are, generally, true.And it is true that Dundee are about to enter a period of games, some of which are must-win, and most of which are must-not-lose, which could define their season.Before the Dark Blues enter into the post-split realm of six-pointers, though, they must navigate five more tough Premiership fixtures.They will be in for some real battlesthey are to pick up points but they have fighters in their squad now which will give the Dee hope they can do it.No one less so than manager Jim McIntyre. He has marshalled a slight upturn in fortunes in recent weeks which has only been offset by the improved form of their relegation rivals Hamilton Accies and St Mirren, also.However, for Macca, it won’t be job done until Dundee are mathematically safe.And that is a long way off, as they sit in the relegation play-off place, three points behind Accies and only one ahead of the Buddies.Tonight, the Tele takes a look at the Dark Blues’ run-in to the split to see where they can pick up much-needed points.Dundee v Hearts # Saturday, March One of Dundee’s four wins this season, and their only one against a team which currently occupies the top six, came at Tynecastle at the end of January.That - success in Gorgie, coupled with the Jambos’ recent struggles – they are without a win in their last four league outings – will give the Dark Blues confidence going into Saturday’s clash at Dens Park.However, the Dee have only won once at home all season and need that to changethey are to have any hopes of staying in the ision.It’s must-win, for me, and I think they will rise to the occasion.Verdict: Three points.Dundee v Celtic # Sunday, March A game in which Dundee will not be judged on come the end of the season but one,they keep it tight at the back, could see them sneak a valuable point.However, I fancy Celtic to go on a really good run as they look to wrap up eight titles in a row under new manager Neil Lennon.They’ll have too much.Verdict: No points.St Mirren v Dundee # Saturday, March One word. Ten letters. Hyphenated. Six-pointer.If the teams go into this one still practically neck and neck, which I expect they will, a win would be extremely valuable for both.However, I feel, with the enormity of the occasion, they will cancel each other out in Paisley.Verdict: One point.St Johnstone v Dundee # Wednesday, April The Dee and Saints have had some tasty encounters in recent seasons and this one should be no dferent with both teams likely to still have plenty to play for.St Johnstone may still be in the mix for the top six while Dundee’s situation is self-explanatory.I fancy the Dark Blues for this one, they play better on the road and have more to lose than the Perth men.Verdict: Three points.Dundee v Aberdeen # Saturday, April You have to go back to November  for the last time Dundee got a win of any sorts against the Dons.That’s a run of  games without a win, with  losses in a row.That run has to end at some point, so I’ll back the Dee for a hard-earned draw.Verdict: One point.Total points: Eight points.That would leave Dundee with  going into the split and, you would like to think, put them in a decent position to stay up. That is, depending on how Hamilton and St Mirren get on with their fixtures .Hamilton – Motherwell , Hearts , Kilmarnock , Livingston , St Mirren .Verdict: Five points.St Mirren – Kilmarnock , St Johnstone , Dundee , Celtic , Hamilton .Verdict: Eight points.That would leave Hamilton level and St Mirren a point behind Dundee.

title: pals make meat loaf themed coffin to bid farewell to dundee entertainer marc
story: Friends of a Meat Loaf-loving entertainer came together to make sure he was given a fitting final farewell.Marc Kingston died suddenly last month at the age of , having had cancer.Born in Peterborough, he had lived in Dundee for more than  years and was a well-loved performer and DJ known as Marc Meat Loaf, who hosted events in the city.This week his friends met at Dundee Crematorium to make sure the performer received a fitting send-off.Marc arrived in a custom- made coffin painted with Meat Loaf’s Bat Out Of Hell album cover and driven in a flame-effect hearse. vw, px"   vw, px"   vw, px"  He was a huge fan of Meat Loaf, whose hits include I’d Do Anything For Love and Two Out of Three Ain’t Bad.The song Objects In The Rear View Mirror was played as guests left the service. Allan Middleton, who had known Marc for  years, helped to organise the funeral.The bespoke hearse was gted by Allan’s brother Angus’s company, Hearses Are Us, and the coffin was made by a company in England.Allan said: “Marc had seen the car in storage, he had admired it on several occasions and we just thought he liked it so it would be nicewe could use it rather than just a normal hearse.“The wake was in the Ambassador, which was close to his heart because he had done a lot of charity work and things there.“Affertons Funeral Care were brilliant. It was very important that he got a real send-off.”Allan said Marc was a generous man and was always looking to help other people.Marc was also well-known for his talented singing and was ruthless at school with those who he didn’t think were up to much – eventhey did go on to have particularly good careers.Tributes after sudden death of Marc, , one of Dundee#s #great entertainers#" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp tributes-after-sudden-death-of-marc--one-of-dundees-great-entertainers embed # secretisjMwEdx" data-secret"isjMwEdx" width"" "" title"#Tributes after sudden death of Marc, , one of Dundee#s #great entertainers## # Evening " frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"Allan said: “He did do a bit of opera when he was younger.“It was a part of him that Dundee didn’t know much about. These secrets came out at the crem. Fiona Riddle was the celebrant. She was fantastic. She went out of her way to make sure it was personalised.“In his first band at school, Marc threw out one of the singers because he thought he was talentless. That gentleman was Andy Bell of Erasure.”A fundraiser is to be held at the end of this month to help pay for the costs of the funeral and the coffin. Any money left over will go to Ninewells Cancer Campaign.Allan added that Marc loved his job and would often say he “couldn’t have a better way of le, I’m so lucky”.

title: Campaigners press on with vision for Inverness park
story: CAMPAIGNERS hoping to transform a historic Inverness park into a vibrant green space are pressing on with their vision, despite suffering a setback.The Northern Meeting Park Group hopes to transfer ownership of the venue in Ardross Street from Highland Council to a community-run organisation in a bid to enable greater public access and breathe new le into its dilapidated buildingsBut its application for a pound, grant to prepare a business plan and carry out surveys has been turned down by the Scottish Land Fund.Following feedback, however, it is now preparing to submit another application in May and is hoping for more positive news.It is also planning to open the usually locked park gates to the public for one week at Easter and another week in the school summer holidays.It is a repeat of a successful two-week trial opening last summer when hundreds took up the chance to enjoy the space for ious uses including family outings, outdoor office meetings and picnic lunches.Leading campaigner Jon Ford hopes to encourage greater use and activities during the opening weeks taking place April ndash and July ndash.ldquoThis year, we also want people to let us knowthey want to form a programme of events and we can seeit is something we can put on, he said.ldquoIf people are out and about in the park there might be a shinty game going on, for example, or a pipe band.Another possibility might be a Teddy bearsrsquo picnic.The group is also in talks with the Care and Learning Allianceabout future possibilities to use the location for childcare provision .In addition, discussions have taken place with the Calman Trust a young peoplersquos service offering housing support, training, employment opportunities, cooking services, about serving refreshments.Jaci Douglas, Calarsquos chief executive, said during discussions with the community over a year ago, flexible and accessible childcare was identied as one of the needs in the area along with a possible use for the park space.ldquoWe have been working closely with the Northern Meeting Park Group on how best to meet that aspiration, she said.ldquoAs an early years charity, Cala is well placed to work with partners to provide a quality early learning and childcare service and we are really excited about the opportunity to do that in close collaboration with the community group, Highland Council and Highland Le Highland as well as with local parents although itrsquos still at the early planning stages. ldquoFriday  Mar  : PM

title: Candlelight tribute for Highland musician
story: A SOPRANO singer has paid tribute to her ldquospecial friend who inspired her to perform a candlelit concert to raise pound for a cancer care charity.Liz McLardy laid on an evening of music and song for Maggiersquos Highlands to show her admiration to staff who lted the spirits of her close friend Helen Sproston in the final days of her le.Mrs Sproston, a -year-old artist and musician who played alto saxophone in the Bonny Vista Social Club, and the Highland Swing band, would have been parted from her beloved Tibetan terrier called Mac had Maggiersquos not allowed friends to bring the dog in for visits while she was being treated at neighbouring Raigmore Hospital.The concert, called Baroque by Candlelight, in which Ms McLardy performed with pianist Tonya Clement and James Ross on clarinet, was held at St Johnrsquos Church in Inverness on February .Poignantly, Mrs Sproston passed away on the same day.Ms McLardy said: ldquoHelen was special. She was just so full of le. She did all sorts of outrageous things like climbing Mont Blanc and she travelled a lot.ldquoShe was a good artist and musician and she loved her little dog. She was unique. Yoursquod never have believed she was in her seventies.Mrs Sprostonrsquos ex-sister-in-law Kay Hall, with whom she attended Altrincham Grammar School in Cheshire, and had held a close bond as the pair married twin brothers, said Mrs Sproston has a son, Stuart, who lives in Barcelona. Her late husband Ron died several years ago.Paying her own tribute, she said: ldquoHelen was a free spirit and a very determined woman. Some people would say she was stubborn and that helped with the diagnosis. She was determined to make best use of the time that she had left.Bonny Vista Social Club guitarist Pete Gavin said he enjoyed Helenrsquos ldquohard-wit and her stoic approach to living and dying.He said: ldquoA couple of us in the band are aware of our own mortality for ious reasons and Helen was a good example for us because her attitude was very much like lsquoitrsquos time for the last song and Irsquom okay with thatrsquo.Fellow band members made a music recording for her, which she wanted to be played at her funeral.She also recorded a few final words which were edited into the track, thanking friends for all their love and good wishes and paying special thanks to the exceptional buddy who ldquosneaked in the GTs during visits.Then the music fades out with her laughter, Helenrsquos parting gt.Friday  Mar  : PM
