title: Demolition of Eastgate Hostel to start soon
story: EVERY effort will be made to keep disruption to a minimum during the long-awaited demolition of an eyesore in Inverness city centre.Work is set to begin on Monday to take down the scaffolding and frontage of the former Eastgate Hostel which has been a blot on the landscape since being gutted by a blaze in April .Inverness city centre manager David Haas said representatives from Highland Council and the Inverness Business Improvement District have been liaising with the agents to work out a programme to ensure the work happens with the least disruption.There would be a temporary narrowing of the thoroughfare to enable the work to be carried out as quickly and effectively as possibly.ldquoWe are working closely with the business community so they understand the need for the works and that we are taking steps to minimise the disruption so as not to prejudice theof their businesses, Mr Haas said.Businesses would still be able to welcome people through their doors.ldquoAs a member of the public you will be able to walk up and down unhindered, he stressed.Talks have also taken place to ensure access for emergency services and deliveries.ldquoEveryone will understand this is an important moment for the High Street and the city, he said. ldquoWe want to give the opportunity to take the building down as quickly and efficiently as possible.The demolition is expected to take  weeks. The plan is for each stone at the front to be marked and set aside for reuse in the rebuild which has now been approved.ldquoI am very pleased that at long last we are going to see activity which is positive and aon the High Street to a usable site in that area, Mr Haas said.ldquoWe are all conscious we have to maintain a proper service to the public. We will not lose sight of that.ldquoThe agents and the contractor are very committed to getting this job done to the highest professional standard.The demolition follows a long-running campaign by the Inverness Courier which ensured the story remained in the headlines.Friday  Mar  : PM

title: Firms are urged to prepare for Brexit
story: BUSINESSES in the Highlands and Islands are not doing enough to prepare for the impact of Brexit, Highlands and Islands Enterprisehas warned.More than two-thirdsof firms who took part in the agencyrsquos latest business  survey in September and October highlighted Brexit as one the main risks they face, with only  per cent believing it posed no risk to their business.Despite this, the survey showed that only  per cent of firms have a plan in place to help them prepare for Brexit, and a fthrecognise that they need to develop a plan.Carroll Buxton, HIErsquos director of regional development, said: ldquoWhile there is still a great deal of uncertainty about how Brexit will affect businesses in the region, some are already taking steps to prepare, and we would encourage others to do so.ldquoThere is help available on the Prepare for Brexit website and from our own website. Through these, businesses can access expert advice to help them plan, including a handy -point Brexit checklist.More than a thirdof businesses that took part in the survey were trading internationally, but respondents had mixed views on the importance to their business of access to the European Single Market. Just over halfregarded this as important while  per cent said it is not important. However, a higher proportionconsidered the single market important to the Scottish economy overall.The free movement of people across the EU was also viewed as important to the Scottish economy by  per cent of respondents, yet only two in fivefelt it was important to their own business.In addition to questions on Brexit and international trade, the business  survey covered other core issues such as economic confidence, business performance and optimism.Almost two thirdssaid they were confident in the regionrsquos economy and  per cent were optimistic about their own performance and prospects.Friday  Mar  : PM

title: Inverness College UHI lecturers on strike again
story: COLLEGE lecturers are on strike today after pay talks failed to produce any agreement.Members of the EIS Further Education Lecturersrsquo Association in Inverness have joined colleagues across Scotland in striking, with another strike set for March .It follows two one-day strikes earlier this year in pursuit of a cost of living pay increase.Picket lines were seen outside Inverness College UHI at Inverness Campus.Talks aimed at averting the strikes broke down without a resolution, leaving representatives for colleges exasperated, according to the Colleges Scotland Employersrsquo Association.John Gribben, the associationrsquos director of employment services, said: ldquoThe Scottish Government has made it clear that there is no more money for lecturersrsquo pay and colleges have to find the pay deal on offer by making cuts.ldquoIf there were any more money available, our priorities would be for additional investment in enhancing studentsrsquo experiences and on further improving college campuses.Friday  Mar  : PM

title: Inverness West residents asked to give their views
story: People living in the Inverness West ward of Highland Council are being invited to take part in two consultation events focussing on the main objectives for the area.Feedback from a similar event last year will be provided and members of the community will be able to see what progress has been made on a range of priorities.Residentsrsquo views on the Riverside Way project, progress with pedestrian crossings over the A, parking and the forthcoming West Link Phase  are very welcome as are any other areas of interest in the ward.In addition there will be drawings and further information on the West Link Phase , with staff available to answer questions.Councillor Graham Ross said: ldquoWe had a great response last year to our ward priority list and members of the community engaged very constructively in telling us about dferent issues and concerns, and suggesting how problems can be tackled."We look forward to sharing the progress made and to hearing of any fresh priorities for the ward. I would encourage as many people as possible to take up this chance to get involved and come along to either of the sessions.Both drop-in sessions will take place on Wednesday, March .The first is from pm to pm at the Bught Stop and the next is from pm-pm in Charleston Academy.Friday  Mar  : PM

title: Keep Safe scheme signs up new Highland sites
story: FRIGHTENED people seeking refuge now have more safe zones in which to get support in Nairn.Police Scotland and the I Am Me charity have welcomed new members to the arearsquos Keep Safe network, which gives people a place to gothey feel frightened, distressed or have been the victim of crime.Nairn Citizens Advice Bureau has joined the initiative, which is delivered in partnership between I Am Me and Police Scotland.The Keep Safe project aims to help people with a disability, feel safe within their community.I Am Me is a community partnership charity developed in Renfrewshire, to raise awareness of Disability Hate Crime.Gill Maclean, manager of Nairn Citizens Advice Bureau, said: ldquoWe are delighted to have been approved as a Keep Safe space and are keen to do all we can help vulnerable people feel safer and, therefore, more likely to venture out into the town.Inspector Judy Hill told the Courier: ldquoThis initiative aims to help vulnerable members of our communities, including the elderly and the disabled, to feel safe and know where to go for help and assistance should they require it.ldquoAll Keep Safe places are approved by Police Scotland.ldquoSometimes due to disability or age-related illness, people can easily become disorientated, lost or become confused, especially in and around unfamiliar surroundings.ldquoKeep Safe can offer a reassurance that there is somewhere people can seek assistancerequired.For more details about the scheme, go online at www.iammescotland keep-safe about-keep-safe Friday  Mar  : PM

title: My Ness art is approved
story: Three residents and Balleary Community Council failed to meet the deadline, although the planners did consider the community councilrsquos objection despite it being late.The artwork, My Ness, was approved under delegated powers, much to the surprise of some city councillors. Delegated powers meant that the application, from Highland Council, was considered by officials and not elected councillors.My Ness is a curved wall sweeping up and over the water which can be used as a seat, a walkway or a viewing .The concerns of the community council and the three iniduals included the impact on wildle and habitats, the deep piling required and possible pollution during construction.Cllr Ken Gowans said: ldquoThis is very disappointing as there are many unanswered questions that that could have been addressed at the planning committee. There are still concerns regarding the future of the fishermanrsquos hut, erosion of the river bank and where the displaced water will go in high water conditions.Cllr Bill Boyd said some people were not behind My Ness, which was to replace the highly controversial tilting pier artwork earmarked for the riverbank at Eden Court until it was ditched two years ago after a public furore. He said there was a question mark over the future of Inverness Angling Clubrsquos hut currently on the site.Zosia Fraser, chairwoman of Balleary Community Council, said: ldquoI think the fair and democratic way of dealing with this would be in open debate.Friday  Mar  : PM

title: New viewing platforms for Inverness riverside
story: A NEW series of "people perches" are to be installed along the River Ness to let people "engage" with the water ndash as a row continues over how plans for a more major piece of waterside art were approved.An artistrsquos impression shows the Rest Space to be sited in Bank Street, opposite the Mercure Hotel, as a set of steps leading to a fenced  over the river.One of several planned for theof the water it is currently in storage, with plans for its installation next month.Designed by Glasgow-based design practice Dress for the Weather it says on its website: "Rest Spaces is one of a series of art initiatives to encourage people to experience and engage with the river as it flows through the city.ldquoIt will encourage people to stop and enjoy the river in a iety of ways: to perch, to explore, to bask, to gather."Councillor Isabelle MacKenzie, chairwoman of the city of Inverness arts working group, which is overseeing the wide-ranging public art programme of which Rest Spaces is one part, said she thought it was ldquorather magnicent.Adding that, cumulatively, the artworks being created along the riverside would make walking in the area a more interesting experience she said: "There might well be some detractors but we are all iniduals."Councillor Ken Gowans, who was a vocal critic of the previous "tilting pier" proposals shelved several years ago, said he was more relaxed about the Bank Street installation."It will be in a very busy and popular location, especially with tourists, and I suspect it will add some interest to that part of the river," he said.Their remarks were made as other councillors continued to voice anger over revelations that the larger scale curving walls artwork proposed for a site close to the Ness Islands has been nodded through by planning officers rather than being put before elected members.Previously called The Gathering Place and My Ness, but referred to as My River Ness in the recently approved application, this artwork involves two crescent-shaped walls curving out from opposite sides of the river.Having been approved by officers under delegated powers councillors have reportedly been told there is now no way to call it in to the planning committeeNess-side SNP councillor Ron MacWilliam said he is set to meet with Inverness city centre manager David Haas over the issue and has called for a special meeting of the city of Inverness area committee."The natural urban environment is a key asset for Inverness and shouldnrsquot be degraded by development where it can be avoided," he said."The commitment by the previous council to spend on the original Gathering Place design, whilst not to everyonersquos pleasure, was based on an economic impact assessment which has never been revised to reflect the new location and design."Common sense tells you that not a soul will visit Inverness to view this utterly boring creation."He added: "As things stand it appears that as a member of the Inverness city committee, a trustee of the Inverness common good fund and member of the south planning applications committee I, and therefore the people I am elected to represent, have not been involved in the decision-making."Inverness West councillor Bill Boyd, who also sits on the planning committee, said he has written to officers to complain about the way the application has been dealt with.However Councillor Graham Ross, depute provost for Inverness, said it was his understanding that the application had been advertised following normal procedures and had failed to attract enough objections to require it to go to committee."The decision to approve was then taken under delegated powers, which means it met with all the planning regulations," he said.Friday  Mar  : PM

title: Smoking not wanted at Invernesss Victorian Market
story: Smokers could soon be made unwelcome around the entrances to Invernessrsquos historic Victorian Market as part of a drive to smarten up the appearance of the shopping arcade.The market itself is officially a smoke-free zone, but two letters sent out to traders asking them not to light up around the entrances have had no effect, it was reported at a meeting of the tradersrsquo association recently.Now market manager Jo Murray is investigating whether it would be legal for the smoking bins currently placed at the entrances to be removed in the hope that this will discourage smokers from congregating there.The meeting heard that among the smoking ldquoculprits at the Church Street entrance to the market are patrons of the neighbouring Market Bar, which shares an access close with the Victorian Market.Mrs Murray admitted: ldquoUnfortunately nothing can be done at the Market Bar entrance as it is private.ldquoHowever, I am checking with the fire service to ensure there is no legislation preventing the fire bins at other entrances being removed.ldquoDropped cigarette butts might become a problemthere are no bins, but litter wardens can fine offenders.The tradersrsquo association meeting agreed that removing the smoke bins at the entrances might help improve the image of the market.It was also agreed that all future Victorian Market literature will also declare it a smoke-free zone.Friday  Mar  : PM

title: sponsored tired of waiting weeks for appointments welcome to aberdeens newest walk in beauty salon
story: Fed up trying to book a nail, lash or brow appointment months in advance so you can get it at a time to suit you  Well, now there’s a solution, thanks to one of Aberdeen’s newest beauty salons.Lash and Lush opened its doors last month and for co-owner Jenna Young, it was vital that the salon suited its clients’ needs, not the other way round. vw, px"  “I’ve been a working mum for the past  years and it’s been so hard to get appointments, unless I booked weeks and months ahead of time.“But even then, with kids your schedule can be unpredictable so that always wasn’t the best way to do things.“I also thought that it would be good for a salon to be open on a Sunday, because people tend to have a bit more time on Sundays.”And in December Jenna decided it was time to make her wishes a reality for other women in Aberdeen.Just over a month later Lash and Lush was up and running. vw, px"  Open six days a weekpeople can just turn up and get treatments.“We don’t take appointments, it’s walk in only, which means you don’t need to wait weeks for an available space.”The team of four highly experienced beauty therapists offers nails , eyelash extensions and volumising, and eyebrow waxing, threading, tinting and henna brows. vw, px"  “Henna brows are a natural way to create a new shape of an eyebrow, or to enhance eyebrows that are pale or have gaps.“And until the end of the month, you can get henna brows for just £.”Jenna added: “Each member of the team focuses on dferent treatments, but every one of them works hard to give customers the look they want.”Lash and Lush is open from am until pm on Tuesdays and Wednesdays and pm on Thursdays and Fridays. On Saturdays they open at am and close at pm and between am and pm on Sundays.Find out more about Lash and Lush on their Facebook page.

title: first residents of new aberdeen housing development to move in next month
story: The first residents of a new Aberdeen housing development are to move in next month.CALA Homes is creating a new community of around  homes at its Craibstone Estate development, where there will also be commercial space and a neighbourhood centre.The first phase of construction comprises of  homes and CALA Homessales and marketing director Fraser Carr said the initial stage of the project is well under way.He added: “Our show homes, which opened just before Christmas, have proven very popular, and we have had signicant interest from a wide range of buyers, including those taking their first steps on to the property ladder, growing families and those seeking their ‘forever’ home.“We have sold four homes at Craibstone Estate so far, and our first residents are due to move into their new homes in April.”

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: honours even for red star in argyll derby
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe Ropework played host to this keenly contested local derby which was watched by a healthy crowd on Saturday February .And for the second time this season, Red Star and Campbeltown Pupils shared the points in a match both sides will feel they could have won.Both sides were struggling for fluency in the opening stages but Red Star settled first and grabbed the opening goal after  minutes. A long ball to the right hand side was met by Ryan Caskie who cut the ball back to Stuart McLean. The youngster took a touch before slotting past the Pupils# goalkeeper to give Star a - lead.Star continued to press and doubled their lead when Coll McCallum robbed the Pupils# defender on the edge of the box before cutting the ball across goal. The unfortunate Pupils# defender could only ert the ball into the empty net, with McLean waiting on a tap in. The game continued at a frantic pace, however, there was no further scoring in the first half and Star went in with a - advantage.Pupils came out with purpose in the second half as they looked to force themselves back into the game, however, it was a howler from Red Star which allowed them back into the match.A square ball across the back resulted in a mix-up between Star keeper Luke Kalache and defender Ben Forbes which allowed Donald McCallum to prod the ball home from just inside the box and Pupils were back in the game at - with eight second half minutes gone.The home side didn’t recover from this and you could sense a nervousness that gave the visitors plenty encouragement. The equaliser arrived with  minutes remaining when good play from Pupils down the right by Soudan saw him get a low cross in which was met by the on-rushing run of Ryan Deans and he finished well to level the score at -.This set up a frantic finish and both sides could have nicked it towards the end. Pupils went close with a headed effort which was clawed to safety while at the other end there was a goalmouth scramble which Star couldn’t convert and both sides had to settle for a draw in the end as referee Jimmy Litster blew for full time.Red Star were dealt a blow as it emerged that captain Aaron Moore suffered a dislocated shoulder. Hopefully this will not keep him out for too long.On Saturday February , Star have another important home game as they look to move off the bottom of the table when they take on Claremont AFC. The game will be played at the Ropework or Joint Campus G # weather permitting # with a pm kick off.

title: john crawford ardrishaig
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowShinty in Mid Argyll has lost one of its great stalwarts with the passing of John Crawford of Ardrishaig after a short illness.John, aged , died in Mid Argyll Hospital on the evening of Thursday February .John was born and brought up in Minard in Argyll. He was a former member of shinty#s South of Scotland area executive council and did a lot of work for the Referees’ Association.He was probably best known for his work with young players in Mid Argyll, organising qualying tournaments of the Aviemore Indoor Sixes tournament for many years. His work for that competition was recognised by the organisers when he was given a special award at Aviemore along with his friend Donnie MacKenzie of Lochaber.John helped reform Kilmory shinty club in the mid s along with Ian MacPhee, the late Kenny MacRae, Roddy Munro and Alex Campbell. He also served on their committee for many years.John had served as a policeman for a short time before working in the quarry at Furnace, then going on to be a very well-known driver with Gleaner Oils, which supported many of his shinty activities with young players in Argyll.John was a great organiser and acted as goal judge in a number of senior shinty finals including the Glasgow Celtic Society Cup and notably the Camanachd Cup Final in Inverness when Gordon MacIntyre of Oban Camanachd scored his famous winner at the Bught Park.John apparently retrieved the ball from the net and lobbed another onto the park for the re-start before presenting the goal-scoring ball to Gordon after the match.John is survived by his brother Jim who played for Glasgow Police and he was pre-deceased by his we Donella. title: a picture of the past written in argylls records
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAt least until Elon Musk builds his time machine, the vast archives held in Argyll are the best way to get an idea of le in the region#s past.A Lochgilphead audience got a flavour of some of the material within two of Argyll#s most extensive and fascinating collections of documents when a roadshow arrived in town to showcase the #Written in the Landscape# project.At Lochgilphead Community Centre, archivist Jen Young outlined the type of archives held by the Live Argyll trust for Argyll and Bute Council including title deeds, personal correspondence, educational records and the history of societies and organisations.Jen has had the task of uncovering and cataloguing  dferent collections of records from landed estates and businesses across Argyll and Bute going back hundreds of years.Co-presenting the event was Hannah Baker, an archivist working on the Written in the Landscape project within the Argyll Papers archive # the documents of the Dukes of Argyll and Argyll Estate dating back to the th century.Within this rich deposit lies a vast source of information. Documents such as rent records, estate census papers, military papers, letters, maps and legal documents can offer a glimpse into the lives of people who lived across Argyll.The two-year Written in the Landscape project is set to wind up in July this year and has entailed cataloguing and digitising the Argyll Estate and other records to make them more accessible to the public.As Hannah and Jen travel round Argyll on their tour, the intention is to offer a local flavour from the archives aimed at each venue.For the Lochgilphead workshop on February , Jen and Hannah presented such erse items as #registers of the poor# and burgh court rolls from Lochgilphead, th century wage books from Kilmory Estate alongside military commission documents from the th century and a  map of the proposed Crinan Canal, surveyed by John Rennie.Each record offers a dferent insight among a treasure trove of detail.The Lochgilphead presentation followed a similar event in Campbeltown in January. Workshops will be held in March on Mull, Helensburgh in April before travelling to Strachur, Dunoon, Inveraray and Tiree in May.Further information on the Argyll Paper records can be obtained by emailing archives@inveraray-castle. For more information on the Argyll and Bute records, contact archives@liveargyll.PICS:Jen, left, and Hannah with some of the records on display in Lochgilphead. aArchivetalkA  letter from Neill Malcolm of Poltalloch offering to call up tenants to defend Crinan Bay against #the enemy# # presumably the French. aArchivetalk

title: ayr bids fond farewell military
story: NewsAyr bids fond farewell as military funeral held for soldier Jock McKelvieAyr High Street came to a standstill as Staff Sergeant Jock was taken on his final journey.ShareByAyrshire Post:,  MAR NewsJocks coffin is carried from the Aud Kirk "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAyr came to a reverential standstill for the military funeral of Staff Sergeant John ‘Jock’ McKelvie, writes Edwin Lawrence. Shoppers stopped in their tracks and shopkeepers stood on their doorsteps to honour an Ayrshire soldier. Police sealed off the High Street to cars as the cortege arrived at the Kirk Port entrance to the Auld Kirk. The silence was broken only by the lament of a lone piper as Jock’s family filed their way into church. Jock’s coffin was carried into a packed service by men of the Scottish and North Irish Yeomanry. His coffin was draped in a union flag and on top were his cap, belt, his campaign medals and a wreath. A dozen colleagues in the firing party formed a guard of honour after the coffin had passed under the  lych gate. Jock, , lived in Dundonald with second we Gigliola, better known as Julie. And he ran a log and firewood business, as well as being a yeomanry reservist. He was laid to rest with full military honours at Drongan where he spent his boyhood and where parents Dan and Rita live. The father-of-two died six days after his armoured car overturned at the Catterick Garrison in Yorkshire on January . Among the mourners in the Auld Kirk was Colonel John Dalrymple Hamilton, who was representing Prince Charles. Provost Helen Moonie of South Ayrshire Council also attended the service. And there was military top brass from both regiments in which Jock served –the Royal Scots Dragoon Guards and the Scottish and North Irish Yeomanry. Other regiments represented included the Royal Engineers, the Royal Artillery, the Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers and the Le Guards. Members of the Army Cadet Force were also present to pay their respects. Jock was  years in the Royal Scots Dragoon Guards, rising to be a Challenger tank commander. He survived tours of duty in Iraq, Kuwait and Kosovo, only to die in a training exercise. Auld Kirk minister Rev David Gemmell described how John McKelvie ‘grabbed le by the throat’ from his earliest days. He wasn’t much of a scholar at Drongan Primary and Auchinleck Academy, but he knew every creature that ran, crawled, swam or flew in the countryside. And a love of the great outdoors was a huge part of his le – whether it was fishing, playing rugby, ski-ing or mountain biking.  He and we Julie were fond of dogs, and Julie taught her big action man how to ride a horse, said the minister. Major Richard Boyle of the Royal Scots Dragoon Guards read the lesson - ‘To every thing there is a season’ from Ecclesiastes. There were hilarious army anecdotes from best buddy JR Ewing, telling how they had shot at each other - with paintballs. J R also mentioned how when Jock was rebuked by a French officer in Kosovo, the big man pointed to his Royal Scots Dragoon Guards cap badge – a French eagle with the word Waterloo underneath. J R, his voice breaking, concluded by saying: “He was the best soldier I ever served with and my best friend.” Former RSDG officer Will Galbraith highlighted Jock’s pride in his regiment, his family and his friends. He said: “He had a strong sense of honour, of right and wrong, and would always stand up for the underdog.” Will said: “He was a big man, with a big voice and a big heart – a big character. But when you really got to know him, he was a big softie – although you wouldn’t tell him that. You had to be aware of those big hands.” Army chaplain Rev Duncan Macpherson said there were bound to be feelings of frustration, anger and regret at the way John McKelvie died. He hoped these would be resolved, adding: “He was someone who was thoroughly tested, who rose to the challenge and who was a thoroughly professional soldier. He was passionate about vehicles and made sure his was ready for any task.” Lt Colonel Toby Gaddum, commanding officer of the Scottish and North Irish Yeomanry, led the congregation in the regimental prayer. Rev David Gemmell brought the church service to an end by poignantly reciting “We Let You Go’. The poem ends: “We love you, we miss you, we want you to be happy. Go safely, go dancing, go running home.” A collection at the end of the service raised vital cash for the Ayrshire Yeomanry Families Fund. story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: college staging wine fuelled feast
story: NewsCollege staging wine-fuelled feast as job cuts loomLeaked emails tell of lavish bash at cash-strapped Ayrshire CollegeShareByStephen Houston:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR News"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCollege bosses have defended holding a celebration to honour their success amid a climate of drastic job cuts and cash problems. Ayrshire College supremos and invited senior staff will stage a sit-down feast later this month to mark five years since its formation. The dinner for  will also include free wine after a sponsored deal by college chairman Willie Mackie. Leaked emails state the claim the college is “now regarded as one of the most successful colleges in Scotland.” But our inside source said: “It adds insult to injury that this celebration is being held less than one week before the final jobs structure is issued to staff. “It is in extremely poor taste given the circumstances of potential job losses due to lack of funds.” Evening classes are having to be cancelled so the event can be staged at the Kilmarnock campus on March . Retiring principal Heather Dunk is also to be honoured during the evening. Chairman Willie Mackie said: “She has made a signicant contribution to Ayrshire for over  years.” Ms Dunk retired on February , leaving an impending restructure which will cost jobs. A consultation ends tomorrowand it has emerged the Private Finance Initiative which built the Kilwinning campus is a huge drain on funds. An email which Ms Dunk sent to staff in January read: “We need to make signicant savings to be financially sustainable due to the costs associated with the PFI, unfunded national bargaining costs and the increasing costs of pensions, utilities and other services. I am very disappointed that an organisational review is necessary, it is not what I want to be focused on in my last weeks as principal. “However, we must manage within the financial allocation we receive in this very dficult fiscal climate.” Under the consultation, one of the four vice-principals would be axed, three directors culled, heads of learning cut from  to nine, and three marketing coms staff would go. Also at risk of the chop are two posts within estates as well as a shake-up of duties among departments. The board of management will approve the final structure and staff impacted will get a severance package. Ayrshire College acknowledged finance was a major challenge for all Scottish colleges but said the dinner costs were met by sponsorship. A spokeswoman said: “Our main financial challenge for the year ahead is to meet the costs associated with the Kilwinning PFI Campus, national bargaining costs and the increasing costs of pensions, utilities and services. “While the Scottish Funding Council has agreed to provide further strategic funds to help manage these rising costs, the college still requires to make signicant savings to secure its financial sustainability and jobs for the future. “We are, therefore, considering proposals for an organisational review. “All staff are aware of the challenges the college faces, and have contributed to a consultation regarding potential efficiencies and opportunities for income generation. “We have just passed our five-year anniversary as Ayrshire College, and have planned an event, ‘Celebrating Five Years of Success. It is important to recognise this milestone and celebrate success – for learners, staff, the college and the region. “We are mindful of the costs of holding such an event and so have secured full sponsorship.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnUniversities and CollegesAyr NewsAyrEducationKilmarnockSchoolsKilwinning

The Royal National Leboat InstitutionAyr branch announced their closure after it struggled to keep afloat. The branch, which has been around for over  years, issued an urgent appeal last November, appealing for a younger generation to pitch in to save the Ayr branch . Committee member and Secretary Robin White, said: “Sadly the number of volunteers helping to run the branch recently has been dwindling, to such an extent that so few are left the AGM came to the sad decision to close the branch down. However, a number of branch members have indicated they still wish to support the RNLI and will now do so via the Troon Branch. “This Branch is looking for new volunteers, soyou would like to help, please get in touch.” Ayr once had its own Leboat, stationed at Ayr Harbour in  under the management of Ayr Harbour Trust.   During the following  years a number of dferent Leboats were in service, one of which was built in Shadwell, London in  for just under pound. This was transported from London to Ayr Station by rail free of charge, by the London and North Western Railway Company. It was taken down Ayr High Street to Ayr Harbour and christened the ‘Janet Hoyle’, after the donor’s we. Eventually in  the RNLI Committee of Management decided to close the station as Troon had a motor Leboat where there was deemed a safer harbour entrance. There was then no RNLI presence in the town until the late ’s when a group of people decided to start a Fundraising Branch. This has been in existence ever since and has raised well over pound, in its time.

title: giant bins placed right outside
story: NewsGiant bins placed right outside a restaurant and pub in scenic townAnger in Troon as bin squad set up town corral without asking anyone for permissionShareByStephen Houston:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR News "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA council works gang put up a new big bin enclosure – right outside a restaurant and pub in the scenic centre of town. Now a row has broken out after it emerged one council department had not even bothered to speak to another. The unsightly corral cluster for five bins was secured in place near The Cross in Troon without any consultation. Troon Councillors have now become aware after a multitude of complaints. The cleansing department is claiming they contacted the planning department about the placing of the bins. But planners are denying any knowledge of a consultation. Troon SNP Councillor Craig Mackay is now leading the charge to find somewhere  for the bins to be situated, rather than outside the Jade Garden Chinese and Macintyre’s bar. He is asking for officials to meet councillors at the spot in Templehill to try and find a resolution. Councillor Mackay said: “We are trying to develop a coherent vision for our town centre. “I’m not convinced this is the best we can manage for such a high profile location. Cleansing regrettably installed these enclosures without any prior consultation. While it is arguably an operational matter that doesn’t require any such input,they had asked any of the councillors or the community council for comment then I am certain we would not have found ourselves in this situation. “The council’s Planning service disappointingly also appear not to have been consulted on the siting or design of this bin store within the conservation area. I don’t wish to play departments off against each other, but would seek to find a community consensus about what is appropriate for our public realm. “This will almost certainly involve an alternative solution for the bins.” A council spokesman confirmed they are investigating, saying: ““We introduced communal bins to keep the litter secure and away from gulls. title: bus-passenger-ordered-to-pay-compensation
story: A -year-old who was abusive towards a bus driverhas been ordered to pay a total of pound at Selkirk Sherf Court.Richard Tindall of Gala Park Gardens, Galashiels, was fined pound for behaving in a threatening or abusive manner on board the bus in Abbotsford Road, Galashiels, on June .And he was told to pay pound compensation to the driver.A video of the incident was played in the courtroom which showed Tindall abusing the driver and then after leaving the bus re-boarded to continue the onslaught.A female passenger was heard to protest when Tindall said, get out this country and go back to where you came from among other obscenities.Procurator fiscal Graham Fraser said there was no screen guarding the drivers compartment so he was a sitting duck in his seat.He continued: "The accused was trying to get off the bus and there was a dispute about the fare."He was trying to force open the doors in the company of his young daughter at the time."He was using words such as scumbag, idiot and stick it up your a***."As the video shows the accused came back on the bus to continue the abuse."People should not be exposed to this kind of behaviour in the course of their employment."Defence lawyer Joe Boyd described it as an unsavoury incident.He explained that his client had got on the bus with his young daughter who had immediately ran up to the back of the bus which had annoyed the driver.Mr Boyd said that Tindall had suffered a traumatic brain injury in October  which sometimes causes him to react to situations.He said: "He can be the most pleasant of characters but the next minute he can descend into something of the opposite."

title: borders-young-musicians-have-plenty-to-blow-about
story: SOME of the best young Borders musicians are set to showcase their talents later this month in Melrose.The Scottish Borders Wind Orchestra, the Borders Chamber Orchestra, the Guitar Ensemble and the Junior Wind Band will all perform at the concert on Monday, March .The performances in Melrose Parish Church have been organised by Scottish Borders Councils Instrumental Music Service.Building on the success of a similar sell-out event held last year, the young musicians, who represent all of the regionrsquos high schools and many of the primaries, will play a wide iety pieces ranging from traditional Scottish through to works by th century Italian composer Palestrina, Abba and Boney M.Local councillor Euan Jardine, who is the spokesman for Culture and Sport at the local authority, said: ldquoIf last yearrsquos event is anything to go by, this promises to be another impressive performance that will give these young musicians the opportunity to showcase their talent and skills in a spectacular way."I would imagine that tickets will disappear quickly so would encourage people to arrive early get themselves a seat so they are able to enjoy what I am sure will be an extremely memorable event.Following this years concert, the Instrumental Music Service will begin recruiting for their next session and are on the lookout for young instrumentalists interested in joining a music ensemble.As well as being able to develop ensemble and performing skills, pupils get the chance to take part in courses and residential weekends supported by the PTA Borders Young Musicians.A range of social activities are also provided along with the opportunity to make new friends.Ticketsfor the Melrose Parish Church concert are available at the door - pound each or pound for concessions.

title: off-duty-cop-accused-of-causing-disturbance-at-borders-hotel
story: A POLICE officer has been accused of causing a disturbance in a Kelso hotel.Pierce Solley is alleged to have produced a police warrant card despite being off duty and intimidate bar staff and challenge others to fight at the Cross keys Hotel on October .It is claimed he refused to leave when asked to do so by event organisers and police officers and behaved in an aggressive and intimidating manner towards customers and staff.The -year-old, whose address was given as c o Police Scotlands Professional Standards Department at Fettes in Edinburgh,pleaded not guilty at Jedburgh Sherf Court to a charge of behaving in a threatening or abusive manner.A trial date has been fixed for March .

title: getting-checked-could-save-your-life
story: A NEW campaign has been launched to encourage people to get checked for cancer.With research highlighting that fear of a potential cancer diagnosis continues to stop people acting, the Scottish Governmentrsquos Survivors campaign aims to illustrate that more people are surviving cancer than ever before, and highlight that getting checked early plays a big part.People are being encouraged to join the movement by sharing what a loved onersquos cancer survival has meant to them, using #MySurvivor in a bid to tell the other side of the story.For more information visit getcheckedearly.org.

title: biggest-parents-evening-comes-to-the-borders
story: A pathway organisation that helps school pupils in the Borders find careers and jobs is hosting the Biggest Parents Evening in Galashiels this week.Developing the Young Workforce Borders are one of  regional groups working in partnership with local employers to showcase apprenticeship and career opportunities as part of Scottish Apprenticeship Week.The local DYW Borders event will be held at Job Centre Plus, Galashiels on Wednesday .The live jobs fair features full-time, part-time and apprenticeship opportunities as well as a CV workshop and information on the SQA Qualications and the apprenticeship family.Sara Ward, Programme Manager with DYW Borders, told us: "The event will provide an understanding of the apprenticeship family while getting rid of the myths and misconceptions."Hosted in partnership with Skills Development Scotland, Borders College and Jobcentre Plus the aim of the event is to promote the fantastic local career opportunities and help parents and carers understand why they should encourage more young people in choosing an apprenticeship in the Scottish Borders."National and local organisations who have already signed up to promote their opportunities at the Biggest Parents Evening include NHS Borders, Oregon Timber, Scottish Borders Council, Works+, McDonald Cardrona Hotel, the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service, Mears Group, Encompass and many more.Sara added: "The event will not only demonstrate a clear commitment from employers to showcase the great opportunities that are available locally but raise the profile of those committed to Developing the Young Workforce."We are very aware that parents are the biggest influencers in a childrsquos career path, therefore we aim to influence the influencers."The event, which runs from pm to pm, is open parents and pupils

title: jim-clark-rally-could-return-this-spring
story: ORGANISERS of the Jim Clark Rally are confident the race willto the roads of the Borders this spring.And they have pencilled in the weekend of May  and .The rally has not taken place since the tragic deaths of three people in .Elizabeth Allan, , Iain Provan, , and Len Stern, , were all killed as a car left the road near Coldstream.Major reviews have since taken place into safety surrounding closed road rally events as well as a fatal accident enquiry.The Scottish Government is now looking at afor both the Jim Clark Rally and the Isle of Mull Rally by bringing legislation into line with the other parts of the UK.A spokesman for the Jim Clark Rally told us: "We have been maintaining contact and continued working with Scottish Borders Council and Police Scotland in hopeful anticipation that rallying couldsooner rather than later."Arrangements and plans are already in place to facilitate a quick resumption of the sport on completion of the parliamentary process."Potential rally competitors, officials, volunteers and fans right across the UK are therefore advised to pencil in two important dates, May  and  , and plan their routes to the eastern Scottish Borders."With a bit of luck and goodwill, it should soon be possible to allow all those interested to confirm their diary date in ink."The recently concluded Public Consultation by the government on the new proposals proved there was an overwhelming desire for awith  percent of all replies being positive.

title: extending-borders-railway-among-21-options-to-improve-transport
story: EXTENDING the Borders Railway line and putting on extra buses to the BGH are two of the options being considered to help shape the future of transport in the region.In a report published today, The Borders Transport Corridors Study outlined  options that could bring benefits to the area.And they include proposals for better bus links to health centres and neighbouring cities as well as the partial dualling of the A and A roads.Cabinet secretary for transport, infrastructure and connectivity Michael Matheson said: "The Borders Transport Corridors Study fulfils our commitment to consider the future transport needs of the area."We have already committed to rail stations at East Linton and Reston and these will be delivered as part of work to improve capacity to Edinburgh. We will now go on to consider a further twenty-one options as part of the Strategic Transport Projects Review , which is being taken forward during the letime of this Parliament.ldquoThe Projects Review is a nationwide appraisal to identy where improvements are needed and guide investment in Scotlandrsquos transport infrastructure over the next two decades."The recommendations made in this study ndash which are underpinned by detailed evidence on problems and opportunities ndash will help ensure the case is made for improvements in The Borders."We look forward to building on the successful partnerships that we have developed as part of the study as we move forward with the next stage of this important work."

title: galashiels-shows-sweet-charity-love
story: SWEET Charity may be about a down-on-her-luck dancehall hostess searching for love.But there was certainly a lot of it coming from the Volunteer Hall audience at the end of Galashiels Operatic Amateur Societyrsquos opening show on Monday night.Led this year by Carla McColgan, the group put on another faultless performance. The story focusses on protagonist Charity Hope Valentine who is desperate to find her Mr Right.She works at the seedy Fandango Ballroom but has dreams of moving on to bigger things.But it may eventually be the performers themselves who reach the top ndash as their talent shone all evening. In the opening scenes Carla, Jan Bairdand Ruth Davidsonwowed the sell-out crowd with their renditions of classics including You Should See Yourself and Big Spender.And just when it looked as though Charity may have found the one when she meets Italian film star Vittorio Vidal, played by Jack McAulay, she ends up spending the night in his closet as his partner Ursulas home.The cast mastered their American accents, while Jackrsquos Italian twang seemed second nature. And he also impressed with his powerful performance of Too Many Tomorrows.Charity however gets her second chance when she gets stuck in a lt with Oscar ndash a claustrophobic accountant hilariously played by Clark Eaton Turner.Clark is no stranger to the Volunteer Hall stage, and it is clear that the versatile actor can turn his hand to anything. Everything looks well for the dance hall hostess, as Oscar proposes.But the wedding plans are dropped ndash and Charity has to find happiness within herself.On an evening of such commanding performances, it can be easy to forget the people who also work so hard behind the scenes to create this spectacle.Producer and musical director Jeff Thomson deserves huge credit as does choreographer Marie McCullough who obviously worked tirelessly.The sets are brilliantly designed and the scene-changes are swt. The orchestra was also given a deserved ovation at the end. There wasnrsquot a note out of place.Sweet Charity is running this week at the Volunteer Hall, Galashiels, until Saturday, March .
